import numpy as np # linear algebra
import pandas as pd # data processing, CSV file I/O (e.g. pd.read_csv)

# Input data files are available in the read-only "../input/" directory
# For example, running this (by clicking run or pressing Shift+Enter) will list all files under the input directory

    for filename in filenames:
        print(os.path.join(dirname, filename))

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

source.bbe14a7b:
# type_1
x = df_1["Type_1"].value_counts()
labels= list(x.index)
colors = ['aqua','limegreen','blue','fuchsia','gray','green',
         'lime','maroon','navy','olive','purple','red',
         'silver','teal','skyblue','yellow','coral','magenta']

# Create a pieplot
plt.pie(x,labels= labels,colors=colors, autopct= "%1.1f%%")

# add a circle & transform it into a donut chart
my_circle=plt.Circle( (0,0), 0.7, color='white')
p=plt.gcf()
p.gca().add_artist(my_circle)
plt.title("Type 1 of Pokémons", fontsize=16)

plt.show()
source.d8ad506f:
sns.set_style("darkgrid")
sns.set(rc={'figure.figsize':(13.5,9)})

t1 = df_1["Type_1"].value_counts()
fig = sns.countplot(x = "Type_1", 
                    data = df_1,
                    color ="c",
                    order = df_1["Type_1"].value_counts().index);

plt.xlabel("Type of Pokémon")
plt.ylabel("Population of Pokémon in the Type")
plt.title("Type 1 of Pokémon")

for i in range(t1.shape[0]):
        fig.text(i, t1.values[i]+1, t1.values[i], horizontalalignment='center')

# plt.tight_layout() - like the look without this for some reasons 
plt.show(fig)

source.1f870c6f:
def stacked():
    t1 = df_1["Type_1"].value_counts()
    t2 = df_1["Type_2"].value_counts()
    
    fig,ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(13.5,9))
    ax.bar(t1.index,t1.values,color='c')
    ax.bar(t2.index,t2.values,color='tan')
    
    ax.set_xlabel('Types of Pokémon')
    ax.set_ylabel('Population of Pokémon in the Type')
    ax.set_title('Total Types of Pokémon')
    
    #plt.tight_layout()
stacked()
source.f6ee47df:
def dualtype():
    dltype = df_1['Type_3'].value_counts()[0:10]
    fig,ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(13.5,9))
    ax.bar(dltype.index,dltype.values,color='k')
    
    for i in range(dltype.shape[0]):
        ax.text(i, dltype.values[i]+1, dltype.values[i], verticalalignment='center')
        
    plt.xticks(
    rotation=45, 
    horizontalalignment='right',
    fontweight='light',
    fontsize='12') 

    ax.set_xlabel('Top 10 Dual Types')
    ax.set_ylabel('Population in Dual Types')
    ax.set_title('Dual Types of Pokémon')
    #plt.tight_layout()
dualtype()

source.d991ceb0:
# Type 13: Normal The Normal type is the most basic type of Pokémon.
They are very common and appear from the very first route you visit.
Most Normal Pokémon are single type,
but there is a large contingent having a second type of Flying.
Pokémon X/Y add several Normal dual-type Pokémon.

Back to Table of Content
source.05800a85: # 1.5 Speed - SPE ## Speed: determines which pokemon attacks first each round Wiki - The Speed stat determines the order of Pokémon that can act in battle. If Pokémon are moving with the same priority, Pokémon with higher Speed at the start of any turn will generally make a move before ones with lower Speed; in the case that two Pokémon have the same Speed, one of them will randomly go first.
source.54675b9c: ## Basic Information of the dataset
source.9282fed3:
### Results form the Speed Distplot & FacetGrid (Type 1)
1. **Bug** type possess big population in the area between **50-90 SPE** (specially in 90 SPE).
2. **Fire, Rock, Psyhic, Dragon and Steel** have the peak at range of **150 SPE**.
3. **Water** type possess population in the areas of **60 & 100 SPE**
4. **Ghost** type has high density in population, particulary in **60 SPE**.
5. **Fairy** type only has a small population in the area **110-120 SPE**.
6. **Fighting** type possess also has only small population in the area of than **40 & 90 SPE**.

source.e03b6ca5:
# Type 14: Dragon Dragons are among the most elusive and powerful of all Pokémon.
Nine legendary Pokémon are part Dragon type and four have legendary-like stats.

They are notoriously difficult to train due to requiring more EXP points per level
than most non-legendary Pokémon, and the fact they evolve much later
and thus are in their weaker forms for longer.
Interestingly, many final-evolution Dragon types have a 4x weakness to the Ice type.

Back to Table of Content
source.d9a92889:
### Results form the Total Points Distplot & FacetGrid (Type 2)
1. **Flying** as Type 2, possess large number of population starts the rage of **250 - 600 Total**
2. **Flying, Fire and Fighting** as Type 2, has the peakest range from **700 Total (up)**
3. **Grass, Steel, Dark and Rock** type also possess high number of population in the areas of **500 Total**
3. **Poison** type seems to have the majority of population in the range of **400 Total**
4. **Bug** and **Normal** type, have small number in population in **300, 350, 500 Total** and have no population in other areas.

source.7231b226:
# Type 1: Grass **Grass is one of the three basic elemental types** along with Fire and Water, which constitute the three starter Pokémon.
This creates a simple triangle to explain the type concept easily to new players. **Grass is one of the weakest types statistically**, with 5 defensive weaknesses and 7 types that are resistant to Grass moves.
Furthermore, three type combos paired with Grass **have 7 weaknesses: Grass/Psychic, Grass/Ice, and Grass/Dark.**
Back to Table of Content
source.6d729d8f: # 1.4 Special Defense - SPD ## Special Defense: the base damage resistance against special attacks Wiki - The Special Defense stat, partly determines how much damage a Pokémon receives when it is hit with a special move.

# Type 7: Rock Rock is a solid type as one might expect. Like Steel, Rock Pokémon usually have high defense
However, since many Rock Pokémon are part Ground they have a 4x weakness to both
Grass and Water whose moves often come as Special type.

Back to Table of Content
source.db34ac4b:
### Results form the Hit Points Distplot & FacetGrid (Type 1)
1. **Water, Rock, Dragon and Dark** have the peak at range of **120 HP**.
2. **Water** type also possess high population in the areas of **90 HP**
3. **Bug** type has very high number in population, particulary in **60-70 HP**.
4. **Fairy** as Type 1 possess low population,only in the rage of **55 & 90 HP**
5. **Flying** as Type 1, as well, possess low population,only in the rage of **30 & 80 HP**
source.ca44a9db:
# Type 16: Poison The Poison type is regarded as one of the weakest offensively.
(many of which are dual Poison so neutralizes the effect).
It now has an extra advantage against the new Fairy type.
In the first generation it was also super-effective against Bug but this was changed.
It fares a little better defensively but its best advantage is through status moves like Toxic.

### Results form the Defense Distplot & FacetGrid (Type 1)
1. **Bug and Steel** as Type 1, have highest defense in the range of **230 DEF**.
2. **Bug, Normal and Water** as Type 1, also possess high poppulation in the range of **40-50 ATK**.
3. **Fairy** type possess no population in the area further than **100 ATK**.
4. **Steel** type is probably the best all Type 1 in terms of defense.
5. **Water** type also possess hight population between the range of **50-90 ATK**
source.52d3567b: #### 1. Highest ATK = Mewtwo(Mega X) [190 ATK]
source.e321d2ae:
## 2.1 Type Population Analysis ### Result * **Water** is the majority of type 1 with 14.0% of population
* **Ground, Ghost, and Dragon** have the same population numbers.
* **Flying** is the majority type as the type 2 with over 20% of population.
* While in type 1, **Normal** type is around 12.3% of the total population, but as a type 2, it only has 1.0%
* **Ground, Poison, Psychic** comes as the 2nd place in type 2.
* **Normal/Flying** type is the most common population for dual types.
* **Legendary** Pokemon is only 8.1% population of total Pokemon
source.4428363c:
# Type 10: Ice Ice type Pokémon are now the rarest of all types: there are only around 60 in total
(depending on how you count alternate forms or mega evolutions).
They are ranked quite well defensively in terms of stats,
although multiple type weaknesses let them down.
Some are based on typical Arctic creatures like seals or yaks, while others are more mythical.

source.557b93d9:
# Type 17: Dark The Dark type was introduced in the second generation of Pokémon games as a measure to balance the types.
In particular, its resistance to Psychic cut down that type's advantage by a long way.
When paired with the Ghost type it was the only type combination to have no weaknesses prior to Gen 6.

Back to Table of Content

source.b54b06bb:
# 1. Stats Analysis Statistics, also known as Stats for short, are values that apply to a Pokémon's abilities in battle.
These values determine such factors as, damage given, damage received, which Pokémon acts first, etc.
Most stats are affected by the individual Pokémon and their level,
while others are exclusive to battle and moves.
source.b542eb6c: # 1.6 Hit Points - HP ### HP: hit points, or health, defines how much damage a pokemon can withstand before fainting Wiki - The HP determine how much damage a Pokémon can receive before fainting.

But, the density of population lies in **40 SPD** as 1st place, **90 SPD** as 2nd, and **60-80 SPD** as the 3rd place. 3. **Bug** type also has only small population in the area of **50-60 & 80 SPD** 4. **Flying, Fairy, Psyhic, Steel and Ghost** type have the peak of SPD at 150 **SPD**

source.050952e1:
# Data The data is downloaded from the Kaggle Datasets by Alberto Barradas! https://www.kaggle.com/abcsds/pokemon
> This data set includes 721 Pokemon, including their number, name, first and second type, and basic stats: HP, Attack, Defense, Special Attack, Special Defense, and Speed. It has been of great use when teaching statistics to kids. With certain types you can also give a geeky introduction to machine learning. This are the raw attributes that are used for calculating how much damage an attack will do in the games. This dataset is about the pokemon games (NOT pokemon cards or Pokemon Go).
source.5635e3b5:
# Features This data set includes, including their number, name, first and second type, and basic stats: HP, Attack, Defense, Special Attack, Special Defense, and Speed. It has been of great use when teaching statistics to kids. With certain types you can also give a geeky introduction to machine learning. This are the raw attributes that are used for calculating how much damage an attack will do in the games. This dataset is about the pokemon games (NOT pokemon cards or Pokemon Go). The data for this table has been acquired from several different sites, including: https://www.pokemon.com/us/pokedex/ https://pokemondb.net/pokedex https://bulbapedia.bulbagarden.net/wiki/List_of_Pok%C3%A9mon_by_National_Pok%C3%A9dex_number > One question has been answered with this database: The type of a pokemon cannot be inferred only by it's Attack and Deffence. It would be worthy to find which two variables can define the type of a pokemon, if any. Two variables can be plotted in a 2D space, and used as an example for machine learning. This could mean the creation of a visual example any geeky Machine Learning class would love. **Type, description and sprites**
Thank you so much pokemondb!
https://pokemondb.net/type
https://pokemondb.net/sprites
https://pokemon.fandom.com/wiki/Statistics#:~:text=Statistics%2C%20also%20known%20as%20Stats,exclusive%20to%20battle%20and%20moves.
**The data as described by Myles O'Neill is:** > **#**: ID for each pokemon
> **Name**: Name of each pokemon
> **Type 1**: Each pokemon has a type, this determines weakness/resistance to attacks
> **Type 2**: Some pokemon are dual type and have 2
> **Total**: sum of all stats that come after this, a general guide to how strong a pokemon is
> **HP**: hit points, or health, defines how much damage a pokemon can withstand before fainting
> **Attack**: the base modifier for normal attacks (eg. Scratch, Punch)
> **Defense**: the base damage resistance against normal attacks
> **SP Atk**: special attack, the base modifier for special attacks (e.g. fire blast, bubble beam)
> **SP Def**: the base damage resistance against special attacks
> **Speed**: determines which pokemon attacks first each round
source.92d46d29:
# Type 3: Water Water is one of the three basic elemental types along with Fire and Grass,
which constitute the three starter Pokémon.
This creates a simple triangle to explain the type concept easily to new players.
Water is the most common type with over 100 Pokémon,
which are based on a wide variety of fish and other sea-dwelling creatures.
As of Generation 6, Water has been paired with every other type.

Back to Table of Content
source.f1374d03:
# Type 11: Psychic The Psychic type has few outright strengths, however, it also has few weaknesses.
In the first generation it ended up being massively overpowered,
mainly due to a complete lack of powerful Bug moves, its only weakness.
Furthermore, a mistake in the game meant that Ghost-type moves had no effect on Psychic
(although this only affected the low-powered Lick).
Generation 2 rectified the situation with the addition of the Dark type along
with better Pokémon and moves of all types.

Back to Table of Content
source.37f1b313:
# Type 15: Steel The Steel type was introduced in the second generation of Pokémon games.
It is the strongest type defensively, with 10 types being not very effective
against it and the Poison type having no effect.
those types now dealing neutral damage.
The Steel type also has the highest average Defense stat in the games.

Back to Table of Content
source.d01230ff:
# Type 9: Ground Ground is one of the strongest types offensively: it is super-effective against five other types (as is Fighting)
and Earthquake is one of the strongest moves in the game with power and accuracy both 100.
Unfortunately, many Ground type Pokémon are dual Rock types, lumbering them with 4x Grass and Water disadvantages.

Back to Table of Content
source.23ed9c64:
# Type 4: Electric There are relatively few Electric Pokémon; in fact only four were added in the third generation.
Most are based on rodents or inanimate objects. Electric Pokémon are very good defensively, being weak only to Ground moves.
Eelektross is the only Pokémon to have no type disadvantages due to its ability, Levitate.

Back to Table of Content

source.23fc50d3:
# Type 5: Flying Most Flying type Pokémon are based on birds or insects, along with some mythical creatures like dragons.
On average they are faster than any other type.

Nearly every Flying type has Flying as the secondary type, usually with Normal.
There are only three pure Flying type Pokémon (Tornadus, Rookidee, Corvisquire),
and four Pokémon with Flying as a primary type (Noibat, Noivern, Corviknight, Cramorant).
As of Generation 6, the type has also been paired with every other type.

source.e650ad36:
# Type 6: Bug Most Bug Pokémon grow quickly and evolve sooner than other types. As a result, they are often very weak.
In Generation I, bugs were almost useless since the few Bug type moves available were very weak.
The situation improved in later games with better moves and an advantage against the Dark type.

source.25d729b4:
# Notebook Introduction Hi Kagglers!
This notebook is my first personal *Exploratory Data Analysis* project, after finishing the data science course.
I decided to work on this data set as a "re-learn" project with repetitive behavior (as you will see in this notebook),
hoping it would help me get used to the python workflow & coding environment.
(and also, because I am a Pokémon main series games' fan)

As I am aware that using only the stats,
will not be able to provide us the absolute measurement of how good a Pokémon is in the game,
considering other factors in the game such as level, movesets, special ability, items and elemental weakness
that can totally affect how you use Pokémons in the games
but I will try to approach this project from the perspective of the Pokémon main series players(VGC format)
To use this data to my advantage in Pokémon Team build and strategic planning.
I will not separate the legendary pokemon and will be using only "Type 1" for the type analysis section.
As a beginner, your feedback is valuable. If you're so kind to leave me a comment on what I did wrong, whether the area I can improve or the better way to things.
source.4d288c92:
### Results form the Special Defense Distplot & FacetGrid (Type 1)
1. **Bug** type possess big population in the area between **50-90 SPD** (specially in 90 SPD).
2. **Fire, Rock, Psyhic, Dragon and Steel** have the peak at range of **150 SPD**.
3. **Water** type possess population in the areas of **60 & 100 SPD**
4. **Ghost** type has high density in population, particulary in **60 SPD**.
5. **Fairy** type only has a small population in the area **110-120 SPD**.
6. **Fighting** type possess also has only small population in the area of than **40 & 90 SPD**.
source.307ac123:
# Type 18: Fairy The Fairy type was introduced in Generation 6 - the first new type for more than 12 years!
Its main intention was to balance the type chart by reducing the power of dragons,
while also giving an offensive boost to the Poison and Steel types.
Several old Pokémon were retyped and new Pokémon introduced.
There are only around 60 Fairy type Pokémon
(depending on how you count alternate forms or mega evolutions), in total slightly above Ice.

Back to Table of Content
